articles.title: Ilia‚Äôs Next Fight Isn‚Äôt Who You Think #ufc
articles.description: The champ is back ‚Äî and no, Chael Sonnen isn‚Äôt talking about himself. He‚Äôs talking about Ilia Topuria. Topuria returning means one thing: massive fights. And on paper, the biggest fight you can possibly make in the sport right now is simple ‚Äî Ilia Topuria vs. Islam Makhachev. Champion vs. champion. Star vs. star. It sells itself. But Chael says pump the brakes. The UFC likely isn‚Äôt booking that unless Ilia gives up his belt or fully commits to lightweight. That‚Äôs a big sacrifice ‚Äî and historically, the company doesn‚Äôt force those moves lightly. Which means the fight we think we‚Äôre getting‚Ä¶ probably isn‚Äôt next. So what is? Enter Justin Gaethje. Chael argues we‚Äôve disrespected Gaethje long enough. This isn‚Äôt just some action fighter ‚Äî this is a true competitor. A guy who doesn‚Äôt wilt under pressure, doesn‚Äôt fold backstage, and definitely doesn‚Äôt fold in the cage. Skill for skill, toughness for toughness, Gaethje is a nightmare matchup for anyone ‚Äî including Topuria. Ilia might be elite. But Justin is something different: proven chaos. If Islam isn‚Äôt next, Topuria vs. Gaethje might be the real superfight hiding in plain sight. #IliaTopuria #JustinGaethje #IslamMakhachev #UFC #MMA #Lightweight #ChaelSonnen #CombatSports

articles.title: Ilia Topuria is the Michael Jordan of MMA‚Ä¶ #ufc
articles.description: Jorge Masvidal just said something that stopped Chael Sonnen in his tracks ‚Äî he called Ilia Topuria the Michael Jordan of MMA. Think about that. Masvidal didn‚Äôt just praise Topuria. He laid out a path to all-time greatness: move up, beat Islam Makhachev, grab a second belt, then chase a third at welterweight. If Ilia holds titles at 145, 155, and 170, Masvidal says you can‚Äôt deny him anymore. Not Jon Jones. Not Georges St-Pierre. Not Khabib. Nobody. Chael breaks down how crazy ‚Äî and how realistic ‚Äî this actually sounds. Because here‚Äôs the twist: Topuria might already be closer than people think. He‚Äôs the featherweight champ, he‚Äôs proven he can compete at lightweight, and he already owns the BMF title. The only reason he‚Äôs not technically a simultaneous multi-division champ? Paperwork and timing. Competition-wise, the skills are there. Power. Boxing. Confidence. Zero fear of moving up. Chael asks the real question: if Topuria beats Islam, does the GOAT debate instantly change? It sounds bold now‚Ä¶ until it happens. Then it‚Äôll sound obvious. #IliaTopuria #JorgeMasvidal #IslamMakhachev #UFC #MMA #GOAT #JonJones #GSP #Khabib #ChaelSonnen

articles.title: Chimaev Won‚Äôt Stop Chasing Pereira #ufc
articles.description: Khamzat Chimaev is doing something Chael Sonnen loves ‚Äî he‚Äôs not letting Alex Pereira breathe. Callouts. Pressure. Constant noise. Chimaev keeps aiming straight at Pereira like a heat-seeking missile. And to Pereira‚Äôs credit? He‚Äôs not ducking anyone. He‚Äôs said it himself ‚Äî big fights, hard fights, grapplers ‚Äî he‚Äôll take them all. There‚Äôs just one problem. They‚Äôre not even in the same weight class. Chael breaks down why this fight sounds great on social media but falls apart in reality. The UFC isn‚Äôt going to book it unless someone vacates a belt or completely changes divisions. That‚Äôs not a small ask ‚Äî that‚Äôs a career-altering move. So how does Chimaev realistically get there? Meanwhile, Kamaru Usman throws fuel on the fire, questioning the rumors that Chimaev walks around at 230 pounds. If that‚Äôs even close to true, what division does he actually belong in? Middleweight? Light heavyweight? Something else entirely? It all creates chaos ‚Äî but it‚Äôs fascinating chaos. Chael explains why Chimaev‚Äôs strategy is smart: stay loud, stay visible, force the company‚Äôs hand. Because sometimes in the UFC, the fight you get isn‚Äôt about rankings‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs about pressure. And nobody applies pressure like Khamzat. #KhamzatChimaev #AlexPereira #UFC #MMA #KamaruUsman #Middleweight #LightHeavyweight #ChaelSonnen

articles.title: Volkanovski is levels above his division #ufc
articles.description: There‚Äôs dominant‚Ä¶ and then there‚Äôs Alexander Volkanovski. Chael Sonnen makes a bold claim in this breakdown: no champion in the UFC has separated himself from the pack like Volk has right now. Not close fights. Not razor-thin decisions. We‚Äôre talking five-round shutouts. One judge literally gave him every single round. And here‚Äôs the scary part ‚Äî the number one contender, the guy who beats everybody else in the division? He‚Äôs still five rounds worse. That‚Äôs not competitive. That‚Äôs a gap. Chael compares it to the all-time greats: Khabib Nurmagomedov, Georges St-Pierre, Jon Jones. Those guys had room to spare. They were so far ahead they could afford an off night and still win. Now Volkanovski is in that same rare air. Chael even floats the unthinkable: if Volk stopped training tomorrow ‚Äî just stopped showing up ‚Äî would anyone beat him in the next two years? Maybe not. Because that‚Äôs how far ahead he is technically, mentally, and strategically. While everyone else is chasing improvements, Volk is already operating at championship autopilot. This isn‚Äôt just a title reign. It‚Äôs separation. And separation is what creates legends. #AlexanderVolkanovski #UFC #MMA #Featherweight #Khabib #GSP #JonJones #ChaelSonnen

Former UFC champion Frankie Edgar floated an idea that instantly got the MMA world talking ‚Äî not calling for retirement, but suggesting that Alexander Volkanovski consider leaving the sport on his own terms. Frankie‚Äôs point wasn‚Äôt disrespectful. It was reflective. Nobody ever truly gets to go out on top in this game. Fighters stay too long. They lose a step. The ending writes itself. Frankie simply asked: what‚Äôs wrong with walking away with your hand raised? Volkanovski has the money. He has the legacy. He has opportunities outside the Octagon. And yet, that‚Äôs never been enough for fighters wired like him. After his dominant performance, many expected a farewell. Instead, the bigger question remains ‚Äî when do you actually call it? Is retirement about no longer being able to compete? Or no longer being able to win? The fighter doesn‚Äôt change overnight ‚Äî only the result does. And that‚Äôs what makes this discussion uncomfortable. History tells us most legends don‚Äôt stop early. Volkanovski doesn‚Äôt seem built that way either. The question isn‚Äôt whether he can continue ‚Äî it‚Äôs how long he should. Watch the full breakdown and decide for yourself. #UFC #AlexanderVolkanovski #FrankieEdgar #MMA #UFCNews #FightAnalysis 0:00 ‚Äì Frankie Edgar Raises the Retirement Question Frankie suggests Volkanovski could retire ‚Äî not a call, but a reflection. 0:32 ‚Äì Why Nobody Ever Gets to Go Out on Top The brutal truth about fighters staying too long. 1:21 ‚Äì The Belief Volkanovski Might Retire Why many thought Saturday night might be the end. 1:52 ‚Äì Why the Rematch Never Made Sense A one-sided five-round fight and the oddity of an immediate rematch. 2:33 ‚Äì How Rare a 5‚Äì0 Title Fight Really Is Why judges almost never score every round one way. 3:01 ‚Äì When Do You Actually Call It? articles.title: Shavkhat Rakhmanov is OUT what now? #ufc
articles.description: Shavkat Rakhmonov is the clear number one contender at welterweight ‚Äî 19 wins, 18 finishes, an absolute monster. But if you take him out of the picture, the entire division suddenly gets weird. Chael Sonnen lays out the problem. If Rakhmonov isn‚Äôt available, now what? Because there‚Äôs one guy you can‚Äôt ignore: Kamaru Usman. Love him or not, Usman isn‚Äôt going anywhere. Former champion, still elite, still relevant. Chael argues the path forward has to include him if you want legitimacy at 170. Then there‚Äôs the fresh blood. Ian Machado Garry vs. Michael Morales? That‚Äôs fireworks. Two young, undefeated (or near-undefeated) contenders, both dangerous, both rising fast. That‚Äôs the kind of fight that actually moves the division forward while the title picture sorts itself out. And then Chael throws out the wild one: Islam Makhachev at welterweight. The idea of Islam being the first man to take Usman down and hold him there sounds crazy‚Ä¶ but would you watch it? Of course you would. Everybody would. That‚Äôs the state of 170 right now ‚Äî contenders, legends, and chaos all colliding. If Rakhmonov‚Äôs sidelined, matchmaking just got very interesting. #ShavkatRakhmonov #KamaruUsman #IanGarry #MichaelMorales #IslamMakhachev #UFC #Welterweight #ChaelSonnen

In this episode of Ask Uncle Chael, Chael Sonnen tackles some of the most persistent questions MMA fans still argue about today. Did he really not know the rules in the Anderson Silva fight? What was Jon Jones actually like behind the scenes on The Ultimate Fighter? And who was the toughest opponent Chael ever faced that nobody talks about? Chael also breaks down why elite wrestlers so often struggle when they transition to MMA ‚Äî and explains the single technical mistake that separates wrestlers who succeed in the cage from those who don‚Äôt. On the surface, it looks like a budget decision. In reality, it‚Äôs a warning sign. Chael Sonnen explains why this move has far bigger implications than one school or one sport. The NIL era was created to fix a real problem‚Äîthe NCAA keeping massive revenues while athletes received nothing. That imbalance needed correction. But the current system has created a new one. Money is now being funneled almost entirely into football and men‚Äôs basketball. Olympic sports‚Äîthe very programs that develop discipline, sacrifice, and long-term excellence‚Äîare being cut to make room. Wrestling is just one of the first casualties. Sonnen lays out a perspective rarely discussed: Olympic sports matter at a national level. Countries take Olympic performance seriously because it reflects something deeper‚Äîdiscipline, resilience, and the ability of young people to train, sacrifice, follow instruction, and succeed under pressure. That same age group, those same qualities, are what nations quietly measure through Olympic competition. And here‚Äôs the part many people miss: Olympic athletes do not come from training centers. They come from universities. The NCAA system feeds freestyle and Greco-Roman wrestling, track and field, gymnastics, and other Olympic disciplines. When college programs disappear, the pipeline collapses. This isn‚Äôt nostalgia. It‚Äôs infrastructure. Cal Baptist‚Äôs decision highlights a growing trend. Olympic sports are being stripped away not because they failed‚Äîbut because the system around them changed. If this continues, the damage won‚Äôt show up immediately. It will show up years later, when the pipeline is gone and can‚Äôt be rebuilt. #Wrestling #NIL #NCAA #OlympicSports #CollegeWrestling #ChaelSonnen #CombatSports #USAOlympics Bad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench

Chael Sonnen believes there is exactly one fighter guaranteed a spot on the UFC White House card: Michael Chandler. Not because of rankings. Not because of wins. But because of loyalty, patience, and timing. If Chandler loses to Conor McGregor, the UFC will want to reward him. Red Panty Night is real, and Chandler earned that opportunity the hard way. He went through The Ultimate Fighter. He waited. He stayed quiet while dates, fights, and promises were dangled in front of him. Through it all, he remained a reliable company guy‚Äîand that matters more than people realize. What‚Äôs changed is the conversation. For the first time, Chandler publicly spoke about a fight that didn‚Äôt involve Conor McGregor. Instead, he talked about the BMF title and specifically mentioned Max Holloway. He even predicted Holloway would beat Charles Oliveira‚Äîthen made it clear he had his eye on that belt. That omission matters. Chandler has always talked about Conor, even when preparing for other opponents. This time, Conor wasn‚Äôt mentioned at all. Behind the scenes, things have gone quiet. McGregor‚Äôs suspension paused the conversation. Then came comments about contracts, phone calls with Ari Emanuel, and uncertainty about timelines. After doing the legwork, Sonnen says this isn‚Äôt public negotiation or chess‚Äîit‚Äôs distance. The Chandler vs. McGregor fight isn‚Äôt happening. So what do you do with Chandler? Big fights are still available. A BMF matchup fits his profile. And regardless of opponent, Sonnen is confident Chandler won‚Äôt just be on the White House card‚Äîhe‚Äôll be on the main card. In a recent conversation, Jones turned down a proposed wrestling match with Daniel Cormier under the Real American Freestyle banner. That part alone isn‚Äôt shocking. What caught attention was the explanation. Jones said he has severe arthritis in his hip and qualifies for a hip replacement. He admitted his last two training camps were a struggle and made it clear that what he has left physically matters to him‚Äîespecially with a young son at home. Officially, all Jones did was decline a wrestling match. But if the explanation is taken at face value, it raises a larger question. If Jones cannot wrestle because of his hip, what does that say about MMA? Wrestling is foundational to mixed martial arts, and the statement inevitably leads people to wonder whether Jones is still physically able‚Äîor willing‚Äîto compete at the highest level. The timing matters. Alex Pereira recently said he would not be fighting Jon Jones at the White House event, and Jones himself made no mention of fighting in this interview. Notably, he also made no reference to the White House at all‚Äîsomething he had consistently done in prior appearances. There is another interpretation. Jones may simply be preserving what he has left for one final MMA run and refusing to spend it on a wrestling camp. Arthritis doesn‚Äôt automatically mean surgery, and declining one competition doesn‚Äôt equal stepping away from another. Still, the silence is new. The absence of callouts is new. And the emphasis on life after fighting is new. Taken together, it‚Äôs fair to ask whether Jon Jones just quietly removed himself from the White House conversation‚Äîwithout ever saying the words. #JonJones #UFC #DanielCormier #AlexPereira #MMA #FightBusiness #CombatSports #ChaelSonnen Bad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench
